awd_titl_txt: Unidata: Next-generation Data Services and Workflows to Advance Geoscience Research and Education
awd_abstract_narration:
Unidata is a community data facility for the atmospheric and related sciences, established in 1984 by U.S. universities with sponsorship from the National Science Foundation.  Unidata's goal is to help transform the conduct of research and education in the atmospheric and related sciences by providing well integrated data services and tools that address the entire scientific data lifecycle, from locating and retrieving useful data, through the process of analyzing and visualizing data either locally or remotely, to curating and sharing the results.  Unidata serves more than five thousand of educational, government, and research institutions that rely on Unidata technologies worldwide.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
NSF Unidata (http://unidata.ucar.edu) is a community data facility for the atmospheric and related sciences, established in 1984 by U.S. universities with sponsorship from the U.S. National Science Foundation (NSF). The NSF Unidata Program Center (UPC), the program office for NSF Unidata and the nexus of activities related to NSF Unidata’s mission, is managed by the University Corporation for Atmospheric Research (UCAR), a consortium that includes more than 130 North American colleges and universities that offer research and education programs in the Earth Systems Sciences.

 

NSF Unidata exists to engage and serve researchers and educators who are advancing the frontiers of the Earth Systems Sciences. Our aim is to help transform the conduct of research and education by providing well integrated data services and tools that address the entire scientific data lifecycle, from locating and retrieving useful data, through the process of analyzing and visualizing data either locally or remotely, to curating and sharing the results.

 

NSF Unidata’s services are provided to members of the education and research community at no (or very nominal) cost. Some of the UPC’s most important activities on behalf of its community include:

 

  • Acquiring, distributing, and providing remote access to real-time Earth Systems Science data.

  • Developing open-source software tools for accessing, managing, analyzing, visualizing, and effectively using Earth Systems Science data.

  • Providing comprehensive training and support to users of its software and services.

  • Providing cyberinfrastructure leadership in the areas of data discovery, access, and use.

 

While NSF Unidata’s primary mission of serving universities engaged in Earth Systems Science education and research has remained unchanged through the years, the evolution and broad usefulness of its products and services have greatly enlarged its user base. Today, the NSF Unidata community includes users from all sectors in over 200 top-level Internet domain countries and territories, including more than 1600 academic institutions and more than 60 research labs. NSF Unidata makes advanced research technologies available to a wide array of existing and emerging research institutions, serving students from a wide array of backgrounds. NSF Unidata software and data services are used at universities in all 31 EPSCoR jurisdictions.

 

The following are some highlights of the Unidata Program’s activities and accomplishments over the course of the award. 

 

  • More than 170 academic or research institutions participated in NSF Unidata’s community-based data distribution network.

  • By participating, these institutions gained access to more than 90 Terabytes of observational weather data and computer simulation output per day at no cost (beyond their own computing infrastructure and network costs). Participants retrieved roughly 2.3 Terabytes of unique Earth Systems Science data per day directly from servers operated by the UPC.

  • More than 1200 community members attended a variety of NSF Unidata workshops and short-courses focused on using NSF Unidata technologies to enhance their research and teaching.

  • Fifteen summer interns joined NSF Unidata staff over the course of the award. Interns expanded their data literacy, software development knowledge, and scientific communication skills — all while making useful contributions to NSF Unidata software projects. 

  • The NSF Unidata Science Gateway project demonstrates end-to-end cloud-computing workflows using resources on NSF’s Jetstream Cloud. One of the Gateway’s most exciting features is a JupyterHub server, which provides students and educators with no-cost access to NSF Unidata-provided Jupyter notebooks illustrating atmospheric science concepts. Over the course of the award, this program has supported atmospheric and related science courses serving over 2150 students at 32 universities. Remote-access resources provided by the Science Gateway were especially useful during the COVID-19 pandemic, when some students were not able to attend courses in person.

  • NSF Unidata’s netCDF software packages (netCDF is data format and set of software libraries for working with data in that format) were downloaded directly from our servers nearly one million times. The netCDF software is also distributed via open source package managers and as part of commercial software products, so downloads from our servers represent only a fraction of the total use.

  • A survey of papers published in American Meteorological Society journals over the project period retrieved 383 papers referring to NSF Unidata software or data services; 1041 papers referring to NSF Unidata software or data services were published in American Geophysical Union journals during the same period. A review of citations reported by the Google Scholar search engine revealed that during the period covered by NSF 1901712, NSF Unidata software and data services were cited 19,947 times in the full range of scholarly literature encompassed by the search engine.

  • In addition to maintaining NSF Unidata’s close association with universities, UPC staff worked to promote community standards across the geosciences by collaborating with other scientific organizations including the Open Geospatial Consortium, NOAA and the National Weather Service, the ESIP Federation, NSF’s EarthCube initiative, NASA, and the U.S. Geological Survey.
